Hello Shane-

It sounds like you have a lot of interesting experience using machine
learning to try to make money in the stock market. Can you give us your high
level view of this area? I am simply curious. Do you think that there are
companies out there that are using machine learning to make money in the
markets, or is the general conclusion that it doesn't work (yet)?

In particular, do you think that anyone is using evolutionary algorithms to
make money? 

We constantly hear about people working on the problem, and there are rumors
that it works, but I have not gotten a general sense of whether it is known
that it works, or known that it doesn't.

PS. You may find this interesting:

http://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/24/business/24trading.html?_r=1&em

I wonder if all of this automated trading hand coded, or if it is something
more based on machine learning (and possibly Eas)...




Cheers,
Jeff Clune

Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University

jclune@...




> From: shanemcdonaldryan <shanemcdonaldryan@...>
> Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Date: Mon, 27 Jul 2009 13:59:08 -0000
> To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Subject: [neat] Re: Time Series Prediction and NEAT
> 
> Spent quite a bit of time working on this problem. Not too successful.
> 
> Go to Metatrader4.com and learn the meta trader language (pretty much c). It
> will allow you create scripts and backtest with historical data to see how
> they perform. If you write a DLL you can even call NEAT via Metatrader.
> 
> I used to work for a company trading futures and I can tell you all the easy
> data mining type trading strategies are tapped out. You'll have to find
> something interesting to make it work. Ideally some sort of leading indicator
> or something very strongly co-ordinated so you can do pairs trading.
> 
> Sliding window would be my advise. But that is a pretty inconsequential detail
> as you'll need much more than a sliding window to make money in my experience.
> 
> Tell me how you do and I can give you my advice. Though take it with a grain
> of salt because I didn't make my billions through this :)
> 
> Regards,
> 
> Shane
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "gururise" <gururise@...> wrote:
>> 
>> Hello,
>> Browsing the archives, its obvious other's have worked on this problem using
>> NEAT with varying degrees of success.  I'm using the rtNeat C++ package under
>> linux and am trying to evolve a time-series predictor applicable to either
>> the stock market or forex markets.
>> 
>> Most of the published research used Neural Networks trained via backprop.
>> These networks typically used a sliding window technique. For example, if you
>> have 1000 days of historical data, a sliding window of 100 would feed the
>> first 100 days of data as input, and the 101st day would be the predicted
>> output from the net. Then the window would slide by 1 day, and you feed the
>> next 100 days and so on an so forth.
>> 
>> I've been trying to use a similar technique with NEAT with very limited
>> success.  For inputs, I use change in price and normalized volume.  The
>> fitness function is basically the inverse of the mean squared error of the
>> predicted outputs vs. the actual data.  The output is trying to predict the
>> change in price at the next time period (it could be positive or negative).
>> I've also switched from the default sigmoid activation function to a bi-polar
>> sigmoid activation that allows for outputs in the range of [-1,1].
>> 
>> How are others using NEAT for time series prediction?  Are you using a
>> sliding window technique, or just have a large input with one output?  Has
>> anyone had success using NEAT to evolve a time-series predictor?
>> 
> 
>
